title-group.article-title: A phenomenological model of two circular turbulent jets

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of British Columbia, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Ehsan Faghani, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of British Columbia, 6250 Applied Sciences Lane , Vancouver, BC, Canada V6T 1Z4. Email: ehsan.faghani@alumni.ubc.ca

abstract.p: A semi-analytical model for the interaction of twin circular jets is developed, requiring the solution of a second-order differential equation for the momentum balance. This model (‘Bending Model’) can predict the trajectory and the attachment of two jets. Using Reichardt’s hypothesis, the three-dimensional velocity field of dual-hole circular jets can be predicted. The model is used to predict the interaction of converging, diverging, parallel and non-equal jets. The results show encouraging agreement with k–ε numerical simulations and experimental results from the literature. The position of the maximum velocity is predicted to within 5%, and the model can predict the velocity field as well as the k–ε model. The current model can be useful in phenomenological engine simulation of multi-hole injectors.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Growing environmental concerns and the optimization of performance of industrial injectors motivate the development of new fuel injection strategies. In some applications, multiple jets are used to improve combustion quality and reduce emission.1–3 For example, non-premixed industrial gas burners may use clusters of turbulent jets (both air and fuel). These clusters can be divergent, convergent or parallel.4 Design of these injectors requires the knowledge of the physical mechanism of attachment of the twin jets. In most industrial applications of multiple jets, circular nozzles are used.

In the flow field of the twin jets, three relevant regions of the flow field are identified, as shown in Figure 1. The ‘converging region’ begins at the nozzle exit and extends to the point where the inside shear layers of the jets join at the ‘merging point’ (mp), also called the ‘confluence point’ in some texts; xmp is the length of the converging zone. Miller and Comings5 showed that the convergence of two plane jets is due to sub-atmospheric pressure near the symmetry line; however, there is no such sub-atmospheric region for two neighboring circular jets.6 The merging point can be identified where the velocity on the symmetry plane increases to positive values. In this paper, to be specified in the definition of the merging point, the merging point is selected to be where the velocity at the symmetry plane reaches 2.5% of the maximum in that cross-section. In the ‘merging region’ beyond the merging point, the two jets start interacting, and the velocity on the symmetry line increases to a maximum value. The merging region ends at the ‘combined point’ (cp), where the velocity profile (in the cross-section) is unimodal rather than bimodal. Finally, the ‘combined region’ is that region downstream of the combined point where the two jets begin to resemble a self-similar single jet.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the dual-hole jet.

sec.p: There are many papers that consider the general flow structure and development of dual-hole circular jets. Okamoto et al.6 measured the mean velocity field of parallel twin turbulent circular jets for two different nozzle–nozzle separations. The twin jets develop an ellipsoidal cross-section that becomes circular far downstream.6 The position of maximum velocity moves from the axis of each nozzle to the symmetry line of the jets. Harima et al.7 studied the turbulent properties of a similar experimental system. Two high-speed parallel circular jets were investigated by Moustafa.8 The effect of stagnation/ambient pressure ratio and nozzle–nozzle spacing on the mean flow field was presented. The mean features of the high-speed twin jets were found to be quite similar to those of low-speed incompressible jets.8

Few studies of non-parallel twin circular jets have been reported. Elangovan et al.9 studied experimentally the interaction of two converging high-speed circular jets. Boushaki and Sautet1 presented an experimental study of flow development and structure of three converging circular jets in reacting and non-reacting flows. The interaction of converging circular air jets for large injection angles (30–120°) for the application of mixing vessels was investigated by Rajaratnam and Khan.10 The flow structure and trajectories of the jets in a strong/weak dual-hole circular jet were studied by Yimer et al.11 As a result of their study, the merging point between the strong jet and the weak jet is a strong function of the linear and angular separations between the jets and their momentum ratio at the exit.11

The analytical solution of single jets has been well studied in the literature. Schlichting12 presented the analytical solutions for individual plane and circular jets. Rajaratnam13 reviewed analytical solutions for different kinds of jets, including a plane jet, circular jet, wall jet and confined jet.

For analytical solution of multiple free circular jets, Reichardt14 proposed that the momentum profiles of individual jets can be superimposed to predict the velocity profiles for flow from multiple nozzles. Pani and Dash15,16 evaluated Reichardt’s hypothesis for multiple three-dimensional free jets. Pani and Dash16 found that the model predicts flow fields for equal-size, parallel jets quite well, but have not considered other cases for diverging, converging and non-equal jets.17 Grandmaison et al.4 introduced a model to predict the curving trajectories of strong/weak jets up to the merging point. They presented results only for momentum ratios above 50 where the strong jet does not bend.

Based on the literature, no analytical model can predict the trajectory of the jets and velocity field for a wide range of parameters. In the present work, we attempt to fill this gap by introducing a new semi-analytical model, referred to here as the ‘Bending Model’, based on the momentum equation of the jets for circular nozzles.
The Bending Model is based on two sub-sections.

list-item.p: The trajectory of an individual jet prior to the merging point is determined by the lateral force on the jet (determined from the y-momentum equation). For the case of circular jets, lateral force is correlated with entrainment of the neighboring jet.
Using modified Reichardt’s hypothesis and knowing the centerline velocity location, ycs, the velocity field in the domain can be predicted.

sec.p: Figure 2 shows the definition of parameters in the Bending Model. The ‘bending ratio’BR=L1/L2 shows the importance of curvature of jets at the merging point cross-section. For a weak jet near a strong jet, the bending ratio is high; for a strong jet, this ratio would be ∼0. In this figure, ycs is the centerline location of the jet and ys is equal to ycs,1−ycs,2. The centerline of a single jet is the location of maximum velocity in each cross-section of the jet. This definition is valid for paired jets too before the merging point. Beyond the merging point, the centerline of each jet remains at the same position (as the merging point), while the maximum velocity moves toward the symmetry line due to the superposition of the velocities.14

The jet half-velocity, b, is the lateral location where
u =

u
m
in that position and it can be approximated as b=Krx. A reasonable estimate of the jet radius is R=1.5b, selected as a radius that covers 95% of the momentum of a single jet, based on the single-jet solution.13 Based on the definition of jet radius, the merging point would be in the position where the distance between two jets is 2R. In Figure 2, L1 is the distance between the injection line and the centerline of the jet at the merging point. L2 is the distance between the centerline location at the merging point and the symmetry plane.
In this work, the Bending Model will be validated by comparing it with previously published measurements and new computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations.

sec.title: Equation of centerline location
sec.p: Figure 3 shows a schematic of the control volume (shaded region) in the x–y plane. In the y-direction, the momentum equation can be written as

caption.p: Schematic diagram of a control volume in the x–y plane.

sec.p: In this equation, u(x), θ(x) and A(x) are streamwise velocity, relative angle and total area of each jet at location x, respectively. The total area of each jet, A(x), is a circle and it is defined based on the diameter of each jet (2R). Equation (1) can be rewritten as

In equation (2), Mn is the lateral momentum flux, which will be defined later by considering the entrainment of the neighboring jet. M(x) shows the total momentum of the jet in location x (i.e. M(x) not the x-component of the momentum). Similarly, u(x) is the streamwise velocity evaluated at location x. We assume that the changes for θ are small in a control volume of width Δx.
Writing equation (2) for the upper jet and assuming the x-component of the total momentum is constant
and applying Taylor series to approximate the functions
where M1 is the total momentum of the jet at the exit nozzle. Equation (4) can be approximated by

In order to estimate the momentum flux on the right-hand side of the equation, the entrainment of the neighboring jet will be considered. This is the key physical factor used to characterize the interaction between jets. According to the correlation presented by Ricou and Spalding,18 the entrained ambient fluid is

In this equation, m is the total mass flux of the jet, M0 is the momentum of the jet, ρa is the density of the ambient fluid and Ke is a constant equal to 0.284. Writing a mass balance gives us a radial velocity of

In this equation, r is the radial distance from the center of the jet. Equation (7) is clearly invalid for very small r, but for the development of the model, it is only needed for r>R. R is the jet radius according to the spread rate (Kr=0.085).4 It is shown in appendix 2 that dMn/dx for the cases Rys can be written as

Here, ys is the lateral distance between two jets. Of course, the existence of the second jet may change the entrainment of the main jet; however, we assume the neighboring jet will not change the entrainment of the main jet that much, and the entrainment rate is uniform all over the jet in a specific radius. Replacing equation (8) in equation (5) gives
Replacing θ with dycs/dx and writing the same equation for the second jet, the equations will be
and

Here, ys= ycs,1−ycs,2 is the distance between the jet centerlines at location x. These two equations can be solved easily by a finite-difference code. In order to relax the assumption that Rys, it is necessary to consider the radial velocity profile in more detail, or introduce a correction factor to the equations. The first approach greatly complicates the solution, so we have added simple correction factors that produce the correct limit for large separations and (as it turns out) work well enough when jets are closer. The modified equations can be written as

No constant is used to tune this equation for the comparisons presented later. Since equations (12) and (13) are expressed as centerline location on the left-hand side and forces on the right-hand side, it is easily applicable for more than two jets by adding the momentum flux of the neighboring jets on the right-hand side. More importantly, the current Bending Model is not limited to the centerline location before the merging point, the centerline location in the entire domain and the velocity distribution will be discussed later in this paper.

sec.title: Centerline location after the merging point
sec.p: Beyond the merging point, the direction of resulting jets can be predicted by considering the momentums of the jets. It was shown earlier by Maxwell and Snorrason19 that
The direction of the interacting jets after the merging point is predicted by equation (14).

sec.title: Reichardt’s hypothesis and modification
sec.p: Reichardt14 proposed a turbulent momentum transfer hypothesis for prediction of flow field in multiple jets. While applying Reichardt’s hypothesis, the square of the velocity, u2, is assumed to be self-similar. Pani and Dash15,16 superimposed the momentum of each jet to predict the velocity profiles for flow from multiple nozzles. For N three-dimensional jets, it is shown that the total momentum is the summation of the momentums over the domain
For the case of two jets, the final velocity in the domain can be found as
In equation (16), u1 and u2 are estimated from the individual jets without interaction. A single-jet profile, where the center of the nozzle is located at (0, 0), can be estimated by

For single circular turbulent jets, the constant values are reported13 as Ka=5.5–7.32, Kr=0.082–0.1. For the case of dual-hole injection in the current study, the constants are selected as Ka=4.85, Kr=0.085 and α=0.60. Equation (17) for two jets can be modified to
and

The velocity profiles predicted by these equations do not properly predict the ellipsoidal cross-section of the interacting jets noted in previous studies.6 Possibly, decreasing the value α for the region between two jets could improve the shape prediction; however, we retained α=0.6 for all comparisons shown below.

sec.title: Validation of the CFD model
sec.p: A CFD model has been used to test the Bending Model for the conditions where there are no measurements. First, however, the CFD simulation must be validated against experiments. A non-uniform unstructured mesh has been adopted for discretizing the flow domain. The total number of control volumes is not the same for all cases; however, the same strategy is used for meshing all cases. In the streamline direction, a geometrically expanding grid has been used with an expansion factor of 1.02. In each nozzle, at least 20 control volumes have been used, and for the region between two jets, a uniform mesh with the same size as the inlet nozzles has been considered. The standard k–ε model has been used to model turbulent flow in the domain for all the cases. In this paper, we use the word ‘CFD’ for the current CFD work. On the inlet region, uniform velocity profile with turbulence intensity I=3.6% has been used. Mesh independence tests have been performed for each case. The maximum differences in the centerline velocity between the coarse and fine grids were 0.5%. These computations have been performed using Ansys-Fluent 14. The total computational time varies case to case; however, an average of 6 hours has been found by considering all the cases. Compared with the ∼1 s computational time of the Bending Model, the current model can reduce the computational time by four orders of magnitude, which is an important factor in parametric studies of engine simulation.

Okamoto’s measurements6 from a steady pair of parallel jets are compared with the numerical simulation (S/d=5, ε=0) in Figure 4, along the symmetry plane at z=0. The numerical predictions match the measurements, except for some deviations in the merging zone (x/d0 = 20−35). The k–ε model is known for its poor performance in the prediction of merging region. The deviation in the prediction of the merging zone has previously been noted in the simulation of twin plane jets using the k–ε model.20 The k–ε model overpredicts the spreading of the jet in the merging zone of a circular jet and, as a result, the prediction of merging zone length is shorter than experimental data. In addition, due to overprediction of the spreading rate, the velocity at the symmetry line is higher than in the experiments (see Figure 4).

caption.p: Velocity distribution of the twin jets at z=0 plane.

sec.title: Centerline location
sec.p: Figure 5 plots centerline locations of dual-hole jets measured by various studies. Figure 5(a) and 5(b) shows the centerline location of the weaker jet in cases where the strong jet does not bend. The results are compared with the experimental results of Yimer et al.11Figure 5(c) and 5(d) consider equal-momentum (twin) jets, so the deviations are symmetrical. Apparently, the Bending Model can predict the centerline location of dual-hole jets properly for a wide range of momentum ratios, injection angles and nozzle–nozzle spacings. In these figures, the Bending Model curves end at the merging point. Following the merging point, superposition will result in the maximum-velocity location shifting towards y=0, but this is not bending in the sense predicted by equations (12) and (13). Instead, this is a consequence of Reichardt’s hypothesis, and is evaluated below.

caption.p: Jet centerline location predicted by the Bending Model and experiments from the literature (a)–(c) and CFD from the present study (d).

sec.title: Velocity distribution
sec.p: Figure 6 compares the Bending Model with CFD results and measurements of twin parallel jets. Although there are small deviations between the Bending Model and the experimental results, the CFD simulation (Figure 4) shows the same difference with the experimental results, which is encouraging. In particular, the biggest error occurs before the combined point on the centerline (y=0), but the CFD results produce nearly the same error in this region.

caption.p: Velocity distribution of the twin jets.

sec.p: Figure 7 compares the velocity contours from the CFD simulations with those predicted by the Bending Model. The Bending Model agrees with the CFD results about as well as the CFD results agree with the experiments discussed earlier. Note that most of the cases considered in Figure 7 are parallel or diverging nozzles (most likely arrangements for fuel injectors), but Figure 7(e) considers a mildly converging nozzle pair, still with good results. Model validation for more strongly converging nozzles, for which impingement effects could be much stronger, has not been attempted. The Bending Model is specifically good at the prediction of the trajectory of the jets, the location of the interaction zone and velocity decay in the streamwise direction. However, in the spanwise direction, the spread of the jet is more than predicted by the CFD simulations.

caption.p: Velocity contour predicted by the Bending Model in comparison with CFD results (white indicates speed less than the lowest value on legend).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A semi-analytical model for dual-hole jets has been developed to predict centerline location and flow fields of two circular jets based on the momentum equation. The results have been compared with CFD predictions (the k–ε model) and previous experimental results. The Bending Model can be applied to diverging, parallel, converging and non-equal jets. No tuning parameter has been used to tune the model for circular jets. The model is able to predict key features of the jet (centerline locations, width of the jet) with approximately the same accuracy as the CFD model, with four orders of magnitude reduced computational effort.

We simplified the equations for the cases of S/d0 1, and then we extended the results for all cases using a correction factor. The cases that we considered here are the practical application of multi-jets in burners and engines, and the results show that the Bending Model works for all the cases. It should also be noted that we considered α as a constant in our prediction; however, a more refined model could vary this.

Although we have considered only isothermal jets in a semi-infinite flow domain, there are reasons to hope that it could be considered in more complex situations. There are some studies in the literature arguing the similarity between parallel jets and offset jets (jets issuing parallel to walls), e.g. Okamoto et al.6 The result of the current model can be applied for those cases by considering the differences in the flow fields. Furthermore, the fundamental principles involved (conservation of momentum) should allow its application to cases of large density differences between the jet and background gas. Thus, it is hoped that the Bending Model can be useful in phenomenological engine simulation of multi-hole injectors.
